title: Puerto Rico statehood movement
summary:
Puerto Rico Status Act

← Previous revision Revision as of 18:31, 3 October 2023
Line 62: Line 62:


===Puerto Rico Status Act===
===Puerto Rico Status Act===
On December 15, 2022, H.R. 8393 passed the House of Representatives in a 233–191 vote with 11 absences. It would have instituted a binding referendum that would allow Puerto Ricans to vote on the future status of the island, that Congress would have to obey. Every [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] voted in favor of the bill, as did 16 Republicans.{{efn|[[Don Bacon]], [[Liz Cheney]], [[Rodney Davis (politician)|Rodney Davis]], [[Brian Fitzpatrick (American politician)|Brian Fitzpatrick]], [[Mayra Flores]], [[Andrew Garbarino]], [[Anthony Gonzalez (politician)|Anthony Gonzalez]], [[Jaime Herrera Beutler]], [[Bill Huizenga]], [[David Joyce (politician)|David Joyce]], [[John Katko]], [[Dan Newhouse]], [[Bill Posey]], [[María Elvira Salazar]], [[Lloyd Smucker]], and [[Fred Upton]].}}<ref>{{cite web |title=Roll Call 529 {{!}} Bill Number: H. R. 8393 |url=https://clerk.house.gov/Votes/2022529 |website=Clerk, United States House of Representatives |date=December 15, 2022 |access-date=December 18, 2022}}</ref> The bill died in the [[United States Senate|Senate]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Warburton |first=Moira |title=Puerto Rico independence vote bill passes U.S. House |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/us/puerto-rico-independence-vote-bill-passes-us-house-2022-12-15/ |access-date=December 18, 2022 |work=Reuters |date=December 16, 2022|quote=...the measure had little chance of being taken up by the Senate.}}</ref> In April 2023, Puerto Rico's Status Act, which seeks to resolve its territorial status and relationship with the United States through a binding plebiscite at the federal level, was reintroduced in the House by Democrats.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Acevedo |first=Nicole |date=2023-04-20 |title=House reintroduces bill to resolve Puerto Rico’s territorial status |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/latino/puerto-rico-status-bill-house-reintroduced-territory-rcna80628 |access-date=2023-06-20 |website=www.nbcnews.com |language=en}}</ref>
On December 15, 2022, H.R. 8393 passed the House of Representatives in a 233–191 vote with 11 absences. It would have instituted a binding referendum that would allow Puerto Ricans to vote on the future status of the island, that Congress would have to obey. Every [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] voted in favor of the bill, as did 16 Republicans.{{efn|[[Don Bacon]], [[Liz Cheney]], [[Rodney Davis (politician)|Rodney Davis]], [[Brian Fitzpatrick (American politician)|Brian Fitzpatrick]], [[Mayra Flores]], [[Andrew Garbarino]], [[Anthony Gonzalez (politician)|Anthony Gonzalez]], [[Jaime Herrera Beutler]], [[Bill Huizenga]], [[David Joyce (politician)|David Joyce]], [[John Katko]], [[Dan Newhouse]], [[Bill Posey]], [[María Elvira Salazar]], [[Lloyd Smucker]], and [[Fred Upton]].}}<ref>{{cite web |title=Roll Call 529 {{!}} Bill Number: H. R. 8393 |url=https://clerk.house.gov/Votes/2022529 |website=Clerk, United States House of Representatives |date=December 15, 2022 |access-date=December 18, 2022}}</ref> The bill died in the [[United States Senate|Senate]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Warburton |first=Moira |title=Puerto Rico independence vote bill passes U.S. House |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/us/puerto-rico-independence-vote-bill-passes-us-house-2022-12-15/ |access-date=December 18, 2022 |work=Reuters |date=December 16, 2022|quote=...the measure had little chance of being taken up by the Senate.}}</ref> In April 2023, Puerto Rico's Status Act, which seeks to resolve its territorial status and relationship with the United States through a binding plebiscite at the federal level, was reintroduced in the House by Democrats.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Acevedo |first=Nicole |date=2023-04-20 |title=House reintroduces bill to resolve Puerto Rico’s territorial status |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/latino/puerto-rico-status-bill-house-reintroduced-territory-rcna80628 |access-date=2023-06-20 |website=www.nbcnews.com |language=en}}</ref>
In September 2023, Roger Wicker reintroduced legislation in the United States Congress on the territorial status of Puerto Rico. a two-round consultation process. The first vote is scheduled for August 4, 2024, where Puerto Ricans will have the choice between four alternatives: annexation to the United States, independence, sovereignty in free association, and a free state associated with the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wicker.senate.gov/2023/9/wicker-reintroduces-puerto-rico-status-act|title=Wicker Reintroduces Puerto Rico Status Act|website=www.wicker-senate.gov|date=September 28, 2023}}</ref>


==Support outside Puerto Rico==
==Support outside Puerto Rico==
